abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that the credit
            served as an effective instrument during the emergency and
            early post-conflict phases in Burundi. It assisted in
            jump-starting a failing economy, stimulated the private
            sector and helped the government provide essential social
            services (especially in education, health and agriculture)
            and to cope with the resettlement of displaced persons and
            returning refugees. It likely helped demonstrate to a wider
            public that the peaceful settlement of conflict was not
            leading instead to greater misery among the
            non-participants. The economic, political and social returns
            accruing from investment in such activities in a
            post-conflict country is considerable, especially in
            Burundi, where the total collapse of the economy seemed
            imminent, due to risks associated with an extremely fragile
            and volatile political environment. However, in order to be
            effective, project design and implementation needed to be
            sensitive to the prevailing circumstances. The most
            important lesson emerging from the project is that in a
            crisis situation where the atmosphere of insecurity was
            pervasive, the degree of flexibility and devolution of
            responsibilities adopted at design stage of the project
            cycle greatly facilitated project implementation. The need
            to pay particular attention to "poverty
            alleviation" components of post-conflict programs
            cannot be overemphasized. The Bank's requirement to
            include these as an integral part of any program proved
            beneficial in the case of Burundi.

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Emergency Economic Recovery
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Through the financing of key imports,
            and essential social services, the emergency Economic
            Recovery Credit Project aims to assist the country in
            maintaining macroeconomic stability, in line with the
            Interim Strategy. The credit will provide, and support
            balance of payments, and increase foreign exchange to
            facilitate private sector imports to prod economic growth.
            The civil conflict hindered economic stability, thus the
            project will be instrumental in the rehabilitation,
            maintenance, and operation of priority sectors. Counterpart
            funding will finance public expenditures in health,
            education, agriculture, and infrastructure sectors, to
            alleviate poverty, and restore peace. Furthermore, the
            operation will assist the Government in re-establishing, and
            improving budget systems, allowing transparency to foster
            foreign external donors. Policy reforms will be supported,
            in an effort to improve macroeconomic performance,
            permitting legislative oversight, and making government
            activities more transparent. However, the risks include the
            potential return to widespread violence, increased military
            expenditures, a reduced political will to negotiate with
            government opponents, and, above all, inadequate efforts to
            achieve budget transparency.
